page.title: 09CHURCHES & CHAPELS, HIGH HAM
page.content: The first church in High Ham was probably Saxon. Later a Norman church was built. The font and some of the tower remain from that period. The present building is 16th century, with beautifully carved bench ends and an impressive oak screen. The sacramental vessels include an Elizabethan chalice and cover. Low Ham church is really a chapelry built in the 17th century on the site of an earlier chapel. The famous Hext plate dating from the 17th century is kept in a bank for safety. The 2 churches,attended by some 12 people each,share a Vicar with 2 other churches. Zion Chapel in Henley and the 19th century chapel in Low Ham are both well supported. Low Ham has a congregation of 30-35 people at twice weekly services. The Chapel Sunday School has a roll of 20, there being no Church Sunday School at present.
